author: m.kalinin
content:
On the security side of 0x02. Please, correct me if I am wrong:

Hacker gets access to the machine that runs the execution client and it changes the coinbase to its address.
In this case we get either block rewards go to hacker's address in case of 0x01 or failed block proposal in case of 0x02.
In both cases staker loses its potential block rewards.

Hacker may also change clients code to the one that allows for randomly picking malicious coinbase from time to time.
Taking in account frequency of block proposals made by solo stakers it doesn't leave any incentives for hacker to do it this way.

Also, we assume that this machine does not run consensus client and hacker is not able to send `SetWithdrawalCredentials` to change BLS creds to its own 0x01 address. And then initiate exit.

Taking in account the above I don't see a big value of 0x02 in terms of protecting inexperienced solo stakers from hackers with any level of experience.
It would only work if following assumptions are held:
- Only the machine with execution client is hacked
- Hacker is looking at validator withdrawal credentials and leaving execution client alone if sees 0x02 kind of creds

Otherwise, we could get even worse result of attack or loss of block proposal rewards (including transaction tips).

author: vgr2774
content:
From a solo staker perspective, if he gets hacked:

- If he used 0x01, he'll have lost his rewards to the hacker, but there's a bigger chance of him not knowing about this potential loss of 
revenue since nothing actually went wrong. (at least not on the surface) The block was successfully proposed and 
the chances of the solo staker finding out at a later time are increased which could lead to more loss of revenue.

- If he used 0x02, neither the hacker or the solo staker will have gotten any rewards, but since he had a failed block proposal,
there's a bigger chance of the solo staker taking notice and fixing any potential security risks in his setup. Personally,
I'd be salty if this occured, but at least the hacker didn't get any reward & on the bright side I can do something about it sooner so that
I don't miss out on future revenue.

If enough stakers follow this reasoning, hackers will have less incentive to perform these kinds of attack because:

- Their target audience becomes smaller due to stakers increasingly fixing their security leaks, denying hackers access.
- Their target audience becomes smaller because they'll be less interested in stakers that have 0x02 set because it's a waste of time for them.
